title: Mean vs Median in Skewed Income
original_question: A community of 10 households has annual incomes (in $10k CAD): 4.5, 5.0, 5.2, 4.8, 6.0, 5.5, 4.9, 5.1, 5.8, 150.0. Calculate the mean and median. Explain why the median is more representative.

segments.text: A community of 10 households has annual incomes (in $10k CAD): 4.5, 5.0, 5.2, 4.8, 6.0, 5.5, 4.9, 5.1, 5.8, 150.0.
segments.explanation: The value 150.0 is significantly larger than the rest of the set, acting as an outlier that will pull the mean upward.
Comparing these two measures reveals the impact of skewness on data interpretation.

segments.text: Explain why the median is more representative.
segments.explanation: In highly skewed data, the median provides a more accurate reflection of the 'typical' experience than the mean.

traps.title: The Average Fallacy
traps.description: Using the arithmetic mean for skewed data often suggests a level of wealth or performance that does not exist for the majority of the sample.

solution.step_desc: Calculate the Median by sorting the data.

solution.content: The mean (19.68) is higher than 90% of the households. The median (5.15) effectively ignores the outlier's magnitude to represent the center.

title: Cross-Subject Performance (Z-Scores)
original_question: Xiao Ming scored 85 in Statistics (Mean 75, SD 10) and 80 in Economics (Mean 70, SD 4). In which subject did he perform better relative to his class?

segments.text: Xiao Ming scored 85 in Statistics (Mean 75, SD 10)
In which subject did he perform better relative to his class?
segments.explanation: Directly comparing raw scores (85 vs 80) is misleading due to different scales and variability.

traps.title: Raw Score Illusion
traps.description: Avoid simply choosing the highest numerical score (85). You must account for how far that score sits from the mean relative to the spread (SD).

solution.content: $Z_{stat} = (85 - 75) / 10 = 1.0$. This score is 1 standard deviation above the mean.
$Z_{econ} = (80 - 70) / 4 = 2.5$. This score is 2.5 standard deviations above the mean.
Comparing $Z_{econ} = 2.5$ and $Z_{stat} = 1.0$, Xiao Ming performed significantly better in Economics relative to his peers.
